Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PAPERS
text: I call the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Mr Lee--- Mr Speaker, I am trying to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PAPERS
text: You have given me no notice that you want to make a personal explanation. If you come and tell me you wish to make a personal explanation, I will give you the call. Now I know you do. I will first call the minister. Mr Leo MCLeay- Mr .Speaker

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PAPERS
text: Have you a point of order? Mr Leo MCLeay-1I have a question I want to ask you. I do not think you have to queue up to ask them, do you?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PAPERS
text: You will sit down. I have called the Minister for Foreign Affairs. NA NA

Speaker: Mr DOWNER
Title: INVESTMENT
text: For the information of honourable members, I present the draft Multilateral Agreement on Investment as at 13 February 1998 and Australia's latest revised schedule of preliminary reservations dated October 1997. NA

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Yes.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: Please proceed.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: I claim to have been misrepresented by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) when he again today repeated the claim that I and my colleagues had made dishonest claims in stating that this government had unilaterally abolished the Commonwealth dental health program. He stated today that the basis of his allegation of dishonesty on my part was that the former Labor government intended to abolish the Commonwealth dental health program. I refer him to page of budget paper No.1 of 1996 that indicates that you claimed a $400 million saving in abolishing the scheme.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: I gather that the honourable member for Watson has a question that he wishes to put to me. He as a former Speaker should know the normal practice in this place has been that you put your name on a list and we know you are going to be called. Mr Leo MCLeay-That's not so.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: It has been in the last 35Mr Leo MCLeay-That has never, ever been so.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: PERSONAL EXPLANATIONS
text: The honourable gentleman should know that, since I have been here, which is somewhat longer than you, it has always been so. Do you wish to put a question to me? Mr Leo MCLeay-1 do, Mr Speaker. NA Speaker: Staff

Speaker: Mr LEO MCLEAY
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, is it a fact that an SES officer of the Department of the House of Representatives is also fulfilling additional duties as your chief of staff? If this is a fact, why was this officer not taken off line and employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984, as has been the practice with all other officers of the department who have worked for Speakers, since you are interested in precedents?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: An officer of the department of the clerk is currently serving as a liaison officer between this House and the Senate. He is not on my staff. He is not employed in the position as an officer on my staff. He is serving as other members of the parliamentary staff do, as a liaison with me, and I have found him very helpful in so doing. He is not replacing any member of my staff nor is he employed in that position. Questions on Notice

Speaker: Mrs CROSIO
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, I wish to raise a question to you understanding order 150 395 and it relates to a question I have on the Notice Paper-No. 2196 put there on 3 September 1997 to the Prime Minister. I ask that you write to him requesting him to answer: is it a fact that he said he would never have a part of a goods and services tax and the question appertaining to it?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: I take the honourable member's question and I will write accordingly. Conduct in the House

Speaker: Dr NELSON
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: Mr Speaker, I have a question to you. Even allowing for the latitude that the Speaker offers to the Leader of the Opposition, day after day we are seeing the Leader of the Opposition rising to take a point of order repeatedly when in fact he is only taking exception to what is being said by the speakers on the government side. I ask you to consider an appropriate form of disciplinary action for the Leader of the Opposition.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: QUESTIONS TO MR SPEAKER
text: As the honourable member for Bradfield and other members know, some indulgence is given to the Leader of the Opposition, but I have noted on a number of occasions a number of members in this place have risen to make some sort of an intervention which does not necessarily accord with the purpose. Certainly, in attempting to raise points of order there has been a good deal of latitude extended. I suggest that all members take note of the concerns of the honourable member for Bradfield. NA Health and Aged Care

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have received a letter from the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely: The failure of the Prime Minister to keep his personal reassurances to older Australians in relation to health and aged care. I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places. More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Who said this: 'We want to assert the very simple principle that truth is absolute, truth is supreme, truth is never disposable in national political life'? Who said that? The member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the current Prime Minister of Australia, who misled the House this afternoon with his dishonest claims about his statements before and after the last election about federal funding for the Commonwealth dental scheme.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The honourable member will withdraw 'dishonest'.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have simply used exactly the same words that the Prime Minister used about me yesterday.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I was not in the chair yesterday and I am now.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: let me draw to your attention page 1302 of Hansard where the Prime Minister said: 'I reject totally any miserable dishonest claim by the member for Dobell.' How can I use exactly the same words and you rule me out of order when the Speaker rules the Prime Minister in order?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have ruled you out of order. I have asked you to withdraw the word 'dishonest'.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Is that your ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I ask you to withdraw.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Is that your ruling?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: It is not a ruling; it is a request for you to withdraw.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I believe the Prime Minister did make a dishonest claim at question time today. Just as he made the allegation against me, I am making it against him. Mr Leo MCLeay-Keep going, Michael.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: No, you will not keep going because yesterday the words used were related to a claim, not to the actual member. I have said that you will withdraw.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Mr Deputy Speaker, if you check the Hansard record, I was very careful-I said the Prime Minister made dishonest claims.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I am not going to check. I am telling you right now to withdraw.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I said the Prime Minister made dishonest claims. I am not going to withdraw something I did not say.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: You are refusing to withdraw?

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Is that your ruling? Is it your ruling that I withdraw?

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: If you want to say that; I do not care what you call it. But, from the chair, I am asking the honourable member for Dobell to withdraw the word 'dishonest' .

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I am not going to withdraw the use of the words, 'It was a dishonest claim of the Prime Minister.' That is the wording I used, and I am not going to withdraw something that I did not say.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I give you one more opportunity to withdraw.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Is that your ruling? If you are going to make a ruling, Mr Deputy Speaker, I will have the opportunity to dissent from your ruling, but please make a ruling.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I am not making a ruling; I do not have to make a ruling. It is not appropriate to make a ruling of this kind. Opposition members-You're in the chair.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I am in the chair, as is pointed out, and I am asking you to withdraw the word 'dishonest'.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The Speaker did not require the Prime Minister to withdraw the use of the word 'dishonest' when it was used against me and my claims.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I warn the honourable member for Dobell. Mr Leo MCLeay-I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. There should be consistency in the rulings from the chair. Yesterday, the precise point that is being canvassed now was canvassed with the Speaker, and the Speaker did not require the Prime Minister to withdraw the words he said about the member for Dobell. If there is to be consistency, and the member for Dobell is using the Prime Minister's own words, then it would seem to be very difficult for you to apply a standard to the member for Dobell which is different to that which your colleague the Speaker applied to the Prime Minister. It would seem that what is sauce for the goose must certainly be sauce for the gander. You have had time for the clerk to give you some different advice now, so I hope he has found a way out of this for you.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I thank the honourable member for Watson for his point of order.

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I just heard the shadow minister for health say to the Leader of the Opposition, 'Will I push him to the edge?' The Leader of the Opposition said, 'Yes.' Is this proper for a discussion like this?

Speaker: Unknown
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Opposition members interjecting

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Order! I would like to sayMr Leo MCLeay-Can we have a ruling on my point of order first? I have taken a point of order, and until it is disposed of--":'

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I have taken a note of the matter contained in your point of order. I ask the member for Dobell to clarify something for me: did you actually claim that the Prime Minister was dishonest?

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: No, I did not. I said that the Prime Minister made dishonest claimsexactly the words he used against me yesterday. Hansard will prove it.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I thought you said that the Prime Minister was dishonest. That being the case, I accept your assurance. Please continue.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Thank you. We believe that this Prime Minister has not abided by that simple act of faith he declared in the past. These are the past words of the member for Bennelong: We want to assert the very simple principle that truth is absolute, truth is supreme, truth is never disposable in national political life. Truth has become disposable in national political life when the member for Bennelong, the Prime Minister of Australia, can give this personal assurance to older Australians before an election and then break that personal assurance once the election is out of the way. This is a letter signed by John Howard, the member for Bennelong, a letter which .is headed up 'A personal guarantee from John Howard'. Mr Leo MCLeay-It's not worth two bob!

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Watson might be right. I am sure there are many older Australians in his electorate who took the Prime Minister at his word when he gave that personal guarantee, when he said: I give you my personal guarantee that, under my government, pensions and other social security and veterans' payments and entitlements will not The Prime Minister - gave that personal assurance that pensioners' entitlements would not be cut. But what has happened? We saw the Prime Minister claim yesterday that this assurance governed only the social security and veterans' affairs payments, it covered only the amount of dollars they received in their bank accounts each fortnight; it did not cover their pensioner entitlements. It was very clear in that personal guarantee from John Howard before the last election-and 'personal guarantee' is mentioned three times in the letter; you would not want to be a banker taking personal guarantees from the member for Bennelong if he can give three personal guarantees in this letter and then break them once the election is out of the way-but certainly yesterday the Prime Minister sought to argue that in some way he was bound to maintain only the payments to pensioners and he was not bound to maintain their entitlements. One of the reasons we are concerned-this was the chart produced by the Department of Social Security outlining the entitlements which pensioners received under the former Labor government-is that there is a whole list of them here: those who have the pensioner concession card, the health care card and the Commonwealth seniors health card. You can see by the marks we have made on this chart how many of these entitlements have already disappeared under this government in just two budgets. In 1996, a pensioner could obtain a copy of this chart at their local Social Security office. It guaranteed to them free basic dental treatment under the Commonwealth dental health program at public dental hospitals and clinics. That was the guarantee in the chart issued by Social Security. That is what we call an 'entitlement'. It is the right to basic, emergency and preventive dental care at the state dental hospitals and through the voucher system at private dental surgeries. What did this government do in its first budget under this Minister for Health and Family Services, the member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge)? It abolished the $100 million going into the Commonwealth dental health program. The be cut. line we get from the government is that in some way the former Labor government also intended to abolish the Commonwealth dental health program. Ms Macklin-Wrong!

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Dead wrong, as my colleague interjects. The proof of that is in the forward estimates for the 1996 budget where it is quite clear that this government claimed a $400 million saving in abolishing the Commonwealth dental health program. How could the current member for Chisholm, the would be member for Casey, claim a $400 million saving in the 1996 budget by abolishing the program if, as he claimed, the program was going to be abolished? That exposes just another element of the hypocrisy and dishonest claims that this government has been making in all sorts of areas of dental entitlement. But it is not just the Labor Party that is raising this issue. A whole series of organisations that represent older Australians are going to scream louder and louder as each day passes because the dental waiting lists are growing as a result of the decision of this minister for health and this government to abolish the Commonwealth dental health program. Let me give you the two examples that we raised with the Prime Minister in this House yesterday. An 82-year-old went to the Royal Newcastle Dental Clinic and was told that her case did not constitute an emergency, even though her dental plate was so loose she could not wear it. Her lower teeth had been ground down to gum level, and she could not eat meat or chew. She was in danger of malnutrition, and she was incapable of travelling all the way to Sydney for an appointment with the dental hospital. We asked the Prime Minister why the government is not prepared to reconsider its decision to abolish the Commonwealth dental health program when 82-year-old women are at risk of suffering from malnutrition because this government will not put enough money into the Commonwealth dental health program.  Robertson supports it.

Speaker: Mr LEE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: The member for Robertson (Mr Lloyd) does support it. The member for Robertson has not spoken up once in this House about his government's cuts to the Commonwealth dental health program. Here is his chance today to speak up and to call on his government to reconsider its decision to abolish the Commonwealth dental health program. He should know that on the Central Coast today, if someone needs emergency dental care on the weekends, it is no longer available because of his government's cutbacks to the Commonwealth dental health program. The second example we gave yesterday was of a man in his seventies from a rural area who had broken a tooth during the weekend. He was quoted $1,000 to have an acrylic crown inserted by a private dental practitioner. As a pensioner, he could not afford this amount of money. He was referred to the local dental clinic where he was told that he would be on a two-year waiting list-this is a man who has a broken tooth in a rural area-as it was not considered to be an emergency. He was also told that he would need to be not only in pain but also bleeding. Is that the way that Australians would expect a man in his 70s in a rural area to be treated? Again, we gave the example today of Women's Health Victoria expressing concern to the Senate inquiry about people being expected to sell their furniture so they can afford to be treated at a private dental surgery because of the cutbacks that this government has made in the Commonwealth dental health program. Let us have a look at what has happened to the waiting times since the government has abolished the waiting periods. In New South Wales, the waiting period has grown from six months to between four and 58 months. In Victoria, it has gone from 12 months to 16 months. In Queensland, it has now blown out to 10 months. In South Australia, it has grown from 16 months to 22 months. In WesternAustralia, it has grown from five months to eight months. In Tasmania, it has gone from two years to 30 months. In the ACT, it has gone from three months to 15 to 30 months. Is it any wonder that ordinary Australians are starting to realise the impact that these cutbacks have had on ordinary Australians? When we asked the Prime Minister today which of these entitlements are now left, which of these entitlements are now covered by his personal guarantee to maintain pensioners' entitlements as well as the payments they receive, the Prime Minister told us, 'Entitlements only mean things that are governed by law.' Entitlements do not mean your right to emergency dental care. Entitlements do not mean your right to some preventive dental care where you get your teeth filled rather than pulled out. Entitlements do not mean that you are entitled to essential medication at a reasonable price because the Prime Minister has unilaterally redefined what a pensioner entitlement is. We are going to hold the Prime Minister to his personal guarantee. When the Prime Minister sends out this personal guarantee to ordinary Australians, he has an obligation to make sure that that dental health program is restored. He has an obligation to make sure that pensioners are not forced to pay $3.20 for basic essential medication when, under the Prime Minister's personal guarantee, it should still be costing them only $2.70. We are going to ensure that this Prime Minister either restores the funding to the dental health program, overturns the cuts in pharmaceuticals and makes sure that Commonwealth senior health care card holders regain access to hearing aids, or issues not just a personal guarantee to pensioners but also a personal apology to all of those older Australians who believed him at the last election, all of those older Australians who perhaps changed their vote to the coalition at the last election because they believed that personal guarantee from the member for Bennelong. I am sure that all of those people today are very disillusioned that their entitlements have been wiped away by this government through its cutbacks in the Commonwealth dental health program, cutbacks in funding for essential medication, cutbacks in access to Australian Hearing Services and massive federal cutbacks to our public hospital system. Is it any wonder that the Australian public hospital system is in crisis when this government cuts massive amounts from the hospital system, the dental care syslem and essential medication to pay for its $1.7 billion failed private health insurance tax rebate? We can give every Australian this guarantee: if there is a change of government at the next election, there will be a real difference. (Time expired)

Speaker: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Chisholm-Minister for Health and Family Services) (3.43 p.m.)The real difference will not come from the member for Dobell (Mr Lee). What a shocker! No wonder he wasted the first five minutes with spurious points of order. No wonder he lent over to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and said, 'Will I push him to the limit?' meaning push you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the limit. If you have so little to say, can understand why you are trying to waste time and avoid this MPI. I will talk briefly about dentistry, and then I will just look at the broader issue of campaign promises both of the former government and of this government. I will then talk about some of the long term things that are happening in health. In dentistry, quite frankly, the Commonwealth dental scheme was a hastily conceived promise by Paul Keating in the dying days of the 1993 election campaign. It was promised for four years. It was promised to treat a certain number of people. It is a program I would have quite liked to have kept going, but we made no commitment to the dental program-as was the case with the former Labor government. It was not mentioned by them in the 1996 election campaign. It was only in the forward estimates, according to the Department of Finance and Administration, because they had made that decision. It was not a conscious decision of the previous government. We could very easily have been fixed, but let us have a look at the words of the Victorian health minister. He said: You can't simply replace 50 per cent of the funding as a result of a Commonwealth decision. In addition to that, it would send a very bad message to the Commonwealth. If any state or territory simply picked up any funding withdrawal, that would only encourage them to withdraw funding from even more programs. There you have it in the words of that state's health minister. It was something you could have fixed. It was something that he understood was the provipce of the state government, but he chose for political reasons not to do it. That is the dental scheme. The dental scheme has been the province of states for 93 years. It is wholly the province of state governments. Some state governments have chosen to pick it up; other state governments have chosen not to pick it up. If a state government chooses not to pick it up, quite frankly, that is their decision, not the Commonwealth's. Looking at election promises, it is illustrative to have a look at what the Labor Party promised in 1993. I have their health policy in front of me. Let me read out some of the I promises the Labor Party made in 1923. One: new initiatives with the private sector for $25 million each year for four years that would be made available to contract to private hospitals elective surgery for public patients on waiting lists. The money was never spent. Two: private hospitals would be included under health services regional planning under the Medicare agreement. It was never done. Three: the aged care industry review would examine the adequacy of nursing staff to meet the increasing dependency of those living in hostels. It was never done. Four: the national rural health program would focus on expanding the rural health centres initiative. It was never done. Five: there would be access to Medicare rebates for bone densiometry for women at risk of developing osteoporosis. It was never introduced for women on a screening basis. Six: the establishment of a national health promotion authority. It was never established. Seven: legislative reform to the National Health Act to ensure Australia's commitment to promotion of health. The legislation was never seen. Eight: provision of language services in public hospitals. The Commonwealth never attempted to make that provision even though it was promised. Nine: the establishment of a national health advisory council on ethnic health. The council was never established. Ten: a continuation of the national health strategy. They abolished it the next year. Eleven: the development of a national primary health care policy. That policy was never developed. Twelve: a national environment health strategy. That strategy was never developed. They are just the broken promises of the Labor Party on pages three and four of their policy. So it is rather galling to have the shadow minister for health come in here and talk about broken promises when you can find 12 blatantly broken promises on pages three and four of their 1993 health policy. I am very happy to stand by our record. I will take honourable members through our record of what we promised in health before the last election and what we have delivered. We promised to retain Medicare and bulk billing. We have retained Medicare in its entirety and we have retained bulk billing. Bulk billing levels today are higher than when we were elected to government two years ago. We said we would retain community rating for private health insurance. It has been retained. We said we would retain the Medicare levy at 1.5 per cent. It is at 1.5 per cent today. We said that we would offer incentives to encourage private health insurance. Those incentives have been delivered and make health premiums for older Australians 18 per cent cheaper than what they would be otherwise. We said that we would retain divisions of general practice. They have been retained and they are part of a quarterly process whereby I have regular meetings with general practice. We said we would reallocate the general practice reform strategies better practice program to cover other initiatives in the health portfolio. It was not a popular decision, but we did it. We said we would retain the community pharmacy agreement and continue the isolated and remote pharmacy allowances under the agreement. That has been retained to the benefit of many rural members in this place. We said that pharmacies would act as Medicare agents. This is one of the great initiatives of this government. Something that many rural members can say with pride is that their constituents now have access to Medicare in a way that they did not have previously. Medicare was a system based on cities. It had largely forgotten rural and remote Australia. By 30 June this year we will have 290 Medicare claiming facilities, at a minimum, in and around rural and remote Australia. We have a health throughout life program that, after two years, is starting to show real benefits. We said we would have a major health campaign to increase the number of women who take folic acid through pregnancy. That is under way. Barely five per cent tb six per cent of Australian women would have supplemented their diet with folic acid yet folic acid supplementation is a very simple way of preventing spina bifid a and other neural tube defects. Spina bifida is a catastrophic condition in children in many cases, although in some cases it can be mild. We can prevent half of that if women who are planning a pregnancy choose to supplement their diets with folic acid. We have Kellogg's and Sanitarium supplementing cereals, all as a result of our health throughout life program. We said we would have a public awareness campaign regarding the benefits of breast feeding, a simple public health preventive measure. That is under way. We said we would have a national immunisation program for mumps, measles and Whooping cough to counter the scandalously low rate of immunisation in this country. We were 68th in the Western world when we came to government, which was the second worse in the OECD. The figures for 1997 show that our immunisation rates for kids under 15 months is up to 76 per cent. It is still not good enough, but it is way better than the 53 per cent that was reported for fully completed immunisation under the ABS surveys. A national diabetes action plan is well under way. We promised it; we delivered on it. It is a significant initiative for people with diabetes, a very important segment of the community. Perhaps 350,000 people know they have diabetes; another 350,000 are walking around not knowing they have it but are subject to all the vagaries and difficulties that the complications of diabetes can bring on. The diabetes action plan is something that is offering real hope to insulin dependent people with diabetes and non-insulin dependent diabetes. Through the action plan, we are implementing a national diabetes register that will give researchers over the next 50 years the capacity to undertake research that will give people with diabetes hope. The healthy seniors initiative is in the process of being delivered. There was additional money for the National Health and Medical Research Council for public health research. That has been delivered in the NHMRC budget. The NHMRC research budget is at an all-time historical record. While we are talking about promises, it reminds me of the promise in 1993 that medical research would reach two per cent of health spending. That was, I have to say, delivered by the Labor Party. They stuck it in the forward estimates and they put it in as a four-year initiative so that the money would drop off the next year. It was a deliberate and conscious decision by the previous government to attempt to hoodwink medical research by saying they would put money into help create a year 2000 spending target but the money only lasted for four years and then dropped off. We have the catastrophic situation at the moment where, if I were to proceed with the forward estimates in medical research, we would be facing a one-third reduction in this country's medical research effort over the next two years. That is the sort of hole I have been left to repair specifically as a result of decisions made by the previous government to try to give with one hand and take with the other. Public health and the National Health and Medical Research Council is being funded in a way and to a level it has never been funded before. We said we would institute a centres of clinical excellence program. That has been delivered. We said we would establish a ministerial council on injury prevention. We have a national injury advisory group working now. We said we would establish hospital outpatient clinics in musculoskeletal medicine. We have provided $7.2 million over three years. That has been delivered. These are very exciting things in public health, preventative health, because our whole health system under the previous government was focused on treating illness, not trying to stop illness in the first place. Musculoskeletal clinics in medicine give us some real chance of getting best practice treatment for people with arthritis, not a particularly fashionable or popular disease but something that causes massive morbidity in this community. We said we would keep life education centres going for primary school education. We have given them $300,000 a year to do it. We said we would continue the national HIV-AIDS strategy. We said we would continue it. We have delivered on that. We have a third strategy now running and with the full cooperation of all the people involved-something this country gets immense credit for. We said we would have a here for life program and allocate $18 million over three years to a national youthsuicide strategy. We have delivered on that. We said we would maintain the rural incentives program. We have. To try to address the crisis in rural health we said we would undertake a number of initiatives. We have delivered on them all. The first one was university departments of rural health. We said we would create six. We have announced seven. The first one is up and running in Broken Hill. The next one will be in Mount Isa. This is a real chance for doctors to go out into the bush and have the backup and support, to have the academic focus, that has previously been only in the cities. The money is not going to buildings on city campuses. The money is going to provide services to rural people to give people a chance to take an academic position in rural Australia and not commit academic suicide. Two professors have just been appointed and they are at Broken Hill at the department of rural health. We said we would undertake John Flynn scholarships. There are now 150 medical students on John Flynn scholarships, again, trying to give young doctors a greater exposure to rural Australia. I met one of the the other day in the electorate of the member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Nairn). If you expose young people to rural practice early on have a better chance of having them go to rural areas. By the middle of this year there will be 300 medical students in Australia John Flynn scholarships-a promise on which we delivered. We have had a locums initiative to try provide better locum relief. We said we would do it. We have done it. We have delivered it. We said we would of nurse practitioners for remote areas in our first term of government. That study is under way. We said we would maintain an area of needs scheme. We have delivered on that. The honourable member mentioned the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. In his own words in this House in 1990 he talked about the enormous cost of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and the need to do something about it. All governments have faced that. When Labor faced that in office they several ways of dealing with it. In the 1995Wooldridge), 96 budget they decided arbitrarily they were going to take $45 million out of the pharmaMinister. ceutical benefits schemes. They did not have any clue how they were going to do it. They asked the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee to find $45 million worth of cuts. Or they arbitrarily increased the safety from $407 to $600 for Australian families-a policy without any logic to it whatsoever; simply an arbitrary cut to the pharmaceutical benefits system. Yes, we have made changes to the pharmaceutical benefits system to make sure it sustainable. If there is one thing that will benefit older Australians it is having a that is sustainable. This year with all the changes we are still spending $200 million $300 million more on' the pharmaceutical J?enefits system than we did in the previous i'ear. We have directed the Department of Emrelevance ployment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and the Department. of Health and Family Services to work on alternative therapies to define training, accreditation and qualification standards. That is under way. them have said we will continue to promote twoyearly pap screening. We have done that. We said we would maintain Commonwealth you funded emergency accommodation for victims of violence. We have delivered. We said there would be no real increase in tobacco excise on in our first term. We have delivered. I ask any member of the public to compare that with 12 specific broken promises on to pages 3 and 4 of the Labor Party election platform for 1993. I am very happy for the public to make that comparison and for us to study a trial stand by that.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Grayndler) (3.58 p.m.)I am pleased to support the matter of public importance before this House, introduced by my colleague the member for Dobell (Mr Lee). It goes to the heart of the issue: this personal guarantee from the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) sent out to pensioners during the last election campaign. We have just heard 20 minutes from the Minister for Health and Family Services, the had honourable member for Chisholm (Dr but we heard nothing in defence of the personal guarantee of his own Prime That personal guarantee is there three times. It says that the coalition would maintain the real value of your pension. That has been broken. It says that they will ensure all Commonwealth pensioner concessions stay net in place. That has been broken. And just to rub it in, the Prime Minister said to pensioners in the lead-up to the election, 'We will keep our word.' They are dishonest claims by the Prime Minister. It is not surprising that the minister has is walked away from the Prime Minister in this debate because the minister is walking away system from his own electorate of Chisholm. He thinks 2.7 per cent is not a big enough marto gin. He thinks 6.6 per cent is what he needs. Mr Ronaldson-On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: that is way, way wide of what is normally general debate. It bears no to the matter of public importance.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I thank the parliamentary secretary.

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: -I am glad the honourWe able member across the table believes that the minister's relationship with his own electorate is irrelevant. I am glad that is the case. He therefore agrees with the minister because he also thinks his electorate is irrelevant. That is why he is walking away from it. What we are primarily debating here today is the $400 million cut in funding by this government to the Commonwealth dental health scheme resulting in its abolition. This is not an abstract issue. This is something that is affecting pensioners right across Australia and, in particular, in electorates such as mine. In March last year, I received a letter from Mrs Elsie Stanley of Edwin Street, Tempe. She wrote: I would seek your help in acquiring a dental plate from Dental Hospital which I applied for in June 1996. I applied last time in September 1996. I can understand money is hard for Government funding. But being on Age Pension it is also difficult for me to replace the one I have which is ill fitting impossible to wear as Dental Hospital removed one of my bottom teeth. I am having difficulty eating as I cannot chew and I am biting the inside of my gum. Elsie Stanley As a diligent and loyal representative-unlike the minister-of my electorate of Grayndler, I wrote to the Chief Executive Officer of the Sydney Dental Hospital on 7 April outlining Mrs Stanley's problem. I wrote: I would be most appreciative if you could consider dealing with Mrs Stanley on a date sooner than is presently planned. I received a letter back on 14 April from Dr Wilkinson, the Director of Dental Services. The letter stated: Due to the high demand, the UDH is currently unable to provide dentures for all patients who need or request them and restrictions have to be placed It was not good enough. I-unlike the member for Chisholm, maybe Casey, maybe somewhere else-am loyal to my constituents. I wrote back to Dr Wilkinson because that was not a good enough response. I wrote: According to Mrs Stanley, upon visiting UDH in June 1996, a gum infection caused the UDH dentist to remove a tooth. Unfortunately, this was the same tooth that Mrs Stanley's plate clipped onto. Mrs Stanley formed the opinion that the UDH, having removed this tooth, would undertake to provide her with a new one to fit the (by now) expanded gap. To this point, Mrs Stanley's expectations seem reasonable. What member of the House would say that this is not a reasonable expectation of a pensioner in my electorate in the working class suburb of Tempe? I got a letter back. I am diligent in looking after those in my electorate. Perhaps the member for Chisholm could take note that this is how you keep your margin. Dr Wilkinson wrote on 7 May 1997: As I previously explained there is a need to place fairly stringent priorities on the provision of dentures. Where one person is accepted it obviously would mean that another person's treatment would need to be delayed. He made an appointment for Mrs Stanley on 14 June 1997 to facilitate her getting treatment. This is the case of a woman, a pensionand er, in my electorate who from June 1996 until June 1997 has had a tooth removed and no bottom plate and who wrote to me as her local member-and I am happy to table this letter-out of desperation because shecannot eat. That is the sort of result of this government's careless, heartless, mean spirited, shameful legislation. Mr MCClelland-Dishonest!

Speaker: Mr ALBANESE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: And, of course, dishonest legislation. It is a breach of the direct promise John Howard gave in writing to pensioners throughout Australia when he was Leader of the Opposition. It is not just that, of course; it goes further. We have the pharmaceutical benefits scheme where the concessional co-payment has been increased from $2.70 to $3.20. We have the impact of the deli sting of a number of pharmaceuticals in the PBS in last year's budget. We also have cuts to Australian Hearing Services which mean hearing aids are no longer available to holders of the Commonwealth seniors health card. The list goes on and on; This is combined with the fact that older Australians will particularly suffer from this government's failed attempt to increase private health insurance by providing subsidies worth $1.7 billion. At the same time, it has taken out $800 million from the public hospital system in Australia which, at the end of the day, is what all Australians, but particularly older Australians, rely on as the fundamental basis of our health system. It is not just that, but the combination of all these changes. Mandy Leveratt from the Brotherhood of St Laurence said: Our research has found that low income earners seek pain relief and antibiotiCs from' their doctors because they cannot afford the cost of dental treatment. We also found that the introduction.of a co-payment meant that people Wyre having to choose between paying their rent or buying food, and their dental needs. That is exactly what has occurred in Mrs Stanley's case. She is being hit by the cuts to the Commonwealth dental health scheme and if she tries to get pharmaceuticals to remove the pain she is hit again. She is being hit over and over again by this heartless government. The list goes on. Because of the cutbacks to the Commonwealth dental health scheme there is increased pressure on every form of dental service. Another family of two unemployed people and three children came into my electorate office. The children have a congenital dental problem which means that they need braces and dental assistance. The first two children were able to get that assistance because they were lucky enough to need it prior to March 1996. Under the Labor government they were able to get support. The third child is unable to get support because of the pressure that has been placed on the system by this government's cuts. If you look throughout the schemes, you have opposition not just from the Labor Party. You have the formation of 'Bite back', which consists of the National Farmers Federationthe friends of the government over there on some other occasions-the Brotherhood of St Laurence and the Au'stralian Dental Association. The list goes on and on. Another group, the Retirement Incomes Conference, has banded together to fight this. It includes the RSL and Westpac retired officers. Across the board there is great opposition to this scheme. There is one other lot of funding cuts to pensioners: by stopping funding to the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, they have lost their ability to complain and fight back against the government's cuts. (Time expired)

Speaker: Mrs ELIZABETH GRACE
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: I rise to support the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) on this scurrilous MPI. I find it absolutely amazing that these people can get up there and say the things that they do. We have been listening to a tirade for the last five minutes about the dental health system. The dental health system is a state issue and has been for the past 93 years. I do not know why we as a Commonwealth government are being blamed for the problems of the Carr government. In Australia today, good government amounts to responding not only to the needs and the desires of the whole population but also to a range of environment forces, not the least of which are economic ones. Good government recognises traditional culture bias in Australia towards private enterprise and free choice. Furthermore, it is based on sound economic management. A Labor government may have introduced universal health care but, as I have said before in this House, they do not have a mortgage on social justice policy. In fact, left in the hands of Labor, the policy foundered because of poor implementation. Cost controls and market demand are foreign concepts to ideology and the Labor government failed to appreciate that social experiments have been abandoned worldwide because of their failure. Those who are foolish enough to criticise this government are indicted by their own dearth of proposals bearing any reference to incentive or promotion in health or aged care. I would just like to refer to a press release that was put out by our minister on 24 March in relation to private health insurance and the fact that it was blocked in the Senate. Had the bill, as the minister said, not been delayed by Labor it would have been possible for it to have been passed this week, as the Senate program gives priority to bills which are deemed non-controversial and are brought on at the earliest opportunity. This decision by Labor means the bill will not be discussed in the Senate until late Mayor early June. This is the politics almost of the indefensible: holding up reforms that the Labor Party supposedly supports just so a handful of boring Labor senators can have their 15 minutes of whingeing or moaning and criticising our incentive scheme for helping 1.2 million people pay their private health insurance premiums. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), the shadow minister and Labor cannot be taken seriously when they hold up measures they supposedly support for purely political reasons. The decision goes against everything the shadow minister told parliament only three weeks ago and suggests that either he misled the House on 5 March or he has been rolled by his so-called leader who just wants to play politics and has abandoned all principles on health. I would also like to refer to a press release released today by my state minister, the Hon. Mike Horan. He was complaining about the failed previous federal member for Lilley and Queensland Labor, who were guilty of using elderly residents at Eventide Nursing Home at Sandgate for purely political reasons. For the past two years, this former member and the Labor Party have been running a disgraceful political campaign of lies about funding and substandard care at Eventide, deliberately causing concern amongst staff, elderly residents and their families. Eventide Nursing Home receives more funding than any other nursing home in Queensland and the staff who have been working there have been providing first-class care. Earlier, a member spoke about the funding to public hospitals. In my own state of Queensland, $38 million for aged care, capital improvements and state owned nursing homes and public hospitals has been added to the budget. Also, there has been an increase Xn funding to allow about 8,000 more elderly Queenslanders to receive home care help services, further increasing the total number of elderly Queenslanders receiving home help care to 94,000. How people could say that we are not supporting and not providing for the aged and older people of Australia is beyond me. Labor governments fundamentally do not understand and cannot manage policy applicable to private enterprise. They do not acknowledge the economic market culture that Australians have chosen since this nation began. They are stuck in a time warp. They would have all of us consume the same public goods and services produced at spiralling costs. It is time they were woken up from their Rip Van Winkle-like sleep and took a look at the real world today. The would be alternative Prime Minister, the Leader of the Opposition-as former Minister for Finance not only ignored the findings of the Gregory report in 1994 but thought it was a good idea to cut capital funds to nursing homes. He had no policy then; he has no policy now. How can he reassure the people of Australia that he will care for them when he has ignored the most damning report that has ever been tabled in this place? Then, to cap it all off, he acknowledged it by cutting capital funding. I would also question why he was allowed to be Minister for Finance when he cannot even do simple arithmetic. In Cairns recently, the Leader of the Opposition stated that if he were elected to government he would provide $150 million a year for the next four years for aged care-a total, as I work it out, of about $600 million. I have no problems with that except that his shadow minister-the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), sitting oppositesaid that in government the Labor party would put $500 million into aged care over four years. Where, oh where, has the $100 million gone? Where, oh where, is it coming from? Who do we believe: the former Minister for Finance, who was so mean as to cut funds to aged care, or the shadow minister, who has already cut $100 million from her leader's guesstimate? This is a party in confusion. Talk about the failure of the Prime Minister to reassure older Australians-what about your failure to reassure older Australians? What are you offering? We are offering $850 million over the next four years for capital improvement in aged care. The best you can do is $500 million or maybe $600 million, depending on what you believe. We have won the capital investment race without any real competition. If your record is anything to go on, the $500 or $600 million will probably end up being $400 million-same old faces, same old policy and the same results: hospitals understaffed, waiting lists, no rural medical services, poor quality aged care facilities and only half our children immunised. What will we get? We will get more of the same. What was it like in 1994-95? It was hopeless. That was why we saw you being swept out of office in 1996. It was the people's response to your health and aged care policies. This government has introduced a plan that will allow nursing home residents the option of renting their homes and having the rental income exempt from pension income tests and from calculation of daily fees. This policy has directed benefits to pensioners. It allows pensioners to keep the family home, it gives them the peace of mind of knowing that some day they may be able to return to their homes and it provides them with a cash flow that does not affect their pensions. No-one will have to sell their home to enter a nursing home. Pensioners will pay tax on their rental home income. However, as taxpayers, they become eligible for a tax rebate of 20c in the dollar on their health care costs that exceed $1,250. They will receive this because, as a result of lots of hard work and talking between our minister and our colleagues, we have been able to get the daily care fees for nursing homes considered as a legitimate health care cost and, therefore, tax deductible. Over the course of a year a resident's daily fees are approximately $7,700. Factor in the 20 per cent tax medical rebate and the $1,250 deduction will be returned to the nursing home resident at the end of the financial year. It must be remembered that this $1,250 is only a base, and the figure does not take into account any related health costs such as medicines or visits to the doctor. I think everyone in this House will agree that a minimum tax rebate of $1,250 as well as a steady rental income will go a long way towards contributing to a person's accommodation charge. This deduction under the medical expenses rebate is a significant for pensioners and their families. This government's policy addresses today's problems and ensures quality care for the future. We have acted where Labor failed. Future generations of Australians will not inherit a $10 billion debt. This government will not stand by and let those of our aged population who are in need of nursing care suffer the indignity of living in substandard accommodation. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has not only given the aged of Australia and those who must access our health systems reassurance but also delivered on his promise of a better deal for all Australians. The Liberal Party understands the need for strategic direction and is not afraid to give birth to new 'ideas. It is ready to ride the waves of change, while Labor would have this country washed up on the sand.

Speaker: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
Title: MATTERS OF PUBLIC IMPORTANCE
text: Mr Jenkins)Order! The discussion - laS concluded. NA Selection Committee Report

Speaker: Mr NEHL
Title: COMMITTEES

The order of precedence and the allotments of time determined by the Committee are shown in the list. The Committee determined that statements on the report may be made-all. statements to be made within a total time of 10 minutes. PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS Order of precedence Notices 1 Mr Zammit to present a Bill for an Act concerning airports in the Sydney area. 2 Mrs Bailey to move: That this House: (1) expresses its concern at the number of bank branches which have been closed in both rural and outer suburban areas; (2) calls on the major banks to honour their responsibility to provide services to their customers and the community as well as delivering dividends to their shareholders; (3) further calls on the major banks to adopt a moratorium on any further planned branch closures until such time that alternative services are made available to their customers and that their customers are educated in electronic banking practices; (4) endorses the Standing Committee on Financial Institutions and Public Administration's investigation into the feasibility of the major banks providing a combined banking kiosk or agency capable of delivering full banking facilities in areas where no bank exists because of branch closure; (5) urges the Government to ensure that departments and agencies are able to utilise alternative banking arrangements such as regional banks, building societies or credit unions where applicable; and (6) notes and supports the Government's financial support of the Credit Care program in rural areas which has provided the means to re-establish financial services through regional banks, credit co-ops and building societies in areas where the major banks have withdrawn services. N otices-continued  That this House: (1) agrees that former Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating's unsuccessful attempt to implement substantial tax reform in 1985 was an acknowledgment of the contemporary failings of the taxation system; (2) recognises that the former Labor Government failed over 13 years to implement substantial tax reform; (3) agrees that the Government's achievement in fixing Labor's $10 billion budget black hole proves that this Government has the resolve and the courage to implement significant and sensible taxation reform; and (4) notes that the Opposition has no plans for substantial taxation refonn and favours a return to the tax and spend policies of the past that led to high interest rates, high unemployment and low growth that had it been allowed to go unchecked could have dangerously exposed Australia in the environment of an Asian financial crisis.
